conclusion: Determine the refractive index of the glass using given distances and refraction properties.
The distance between points A and B is given as sqrt(2)R/2.
The distance between points A and B is also given as 0.26R.
The light travels from point A to point B after being refracted at the interface.
The path of the light can be analyzed using Snell's law and refraction properties.
The distance AB can be broken down into path lengths in glass and air.
The path in the glass is determined by the angle of incidence and refraction.
The distance AB can be expressed in terms of refractive index n and problem geometry.
The distance AB is the hypotenuse of a right triangle in the glass.
The distance in air is the horizontal component.
The distance AB in glass can be expressed using the right triangle formed by the light path.
The distance AB is the hypotenuse of a right triangle with legs R sin(theta) and R cos(theta).
Theta is the angle of incidence.
The distance AB in air is the horizontal component, R tan(theta).
Using given distances, set up equation for total distance AB and solve for refractive index n.
The distance AB in glass is sqrt(2)R/2 and in air is 0.26R.
Total distance is the sum of these two distances.
By solving the equations, the refractive index n is sqrt(2).
The refractive index of the glass is sqrt(2).
